metadata.synopsis: Astarion's default dialog - the dialog you'll get if you speak to him while you're just wandering around in the world. This will cover many different topics, filling out his background and expanding on plot points as they happen in the game. Be aware that at the start of the game, players will not be aware that Astarion is a vampire. These nodes have been marked in the context field.
metadata.how_to_trigger: Recruit Companion Astarion.Speak to Companion Astarion.

16.speaker: Astarion
16.text: You really ended things with Lae'zel, just to be with me?

434.speaker: Astarion
434.text: Not that there was any doubt - I was the obvious choice, but...

213.speaker: Astarion
213.text: Well, perhaps there was a smidge of doubt. I do come with my complications.

50.speaker: Player
50.text: Who among us doesn't, I ask you.

296.speaker: Astarion
296.text: Not everyone lusts for blood, darling. Or could be cursed to an eternity in the shadows if they lose their brain parasite.

4.speaker: Astarion
4.text: Well... you do lust for blood, but you know what I mean.

85.speaker: Astarion
85.text: My point is you didn't have to choose this.

821.speaker: Player
821.text: But I did. I want this. I want you.

812.speaker: Player
812.text: I've made my decision, so you'd better get used to it.

766.speaker: Astarion
766.text: Well, if you insist on loving and adoring me, I guess I'll have to allow it.

694.speaker: Astarion
694.text: You know, darling, I think we are going to have a lot of fun together.

758.speaker: Player
758.text: Don't worry - if I don't like it, I'll just leave you.

836.speaker: Astarion
836.text: Not exactly a resounding declaration of love, but... maybe that's for the best.

269.speaker: Astarion
269.text: All right. Let's see what happens.

31.speaker: Player
31.text: Maybe I like complications. They keep things interesting.

131.speaker: Astarion
131.text: Oh, I can do interesting. It's everything else that worries me.

41.speaker: Player
41.text: We may be a disaster, but I want to see what happens.

165.speaker: Astarion
165.text: I realise now I've never really had anyone. Not really. Nothing that compares to you.

640.speaker: Player
640.text: I was never really serious about Karlach.

522.speaker: Player
522.text: I was never really serious about Lae'zel.

840.speaker: Player
840.text: I was never really serious about Gale.

260.speaker: Player
260.text: I was never really serious about Wyll.

398.speaker: Astarion
398.text: But you're serious about this? About... us?

644.speaker: Astarion
644.text: Five seconds into this relationship and I already want to break up with you.

378.speaker: Astarion
378.text: Still, if you insist on adoring me, then who am I to stop you?

205.speaker: Player
205.text: No, but let's see what happens.

636.speaker: Player
636.text: I was never really serious about Shadowheart.

18.speaker: Astarion
18.context: NodeContext: We don't know he's a vampire yet.

645.speaker: Player
645.context: NodeContext: We don't know he's a vampire yet.

780.speaker: Astarion
780.text: Oh, what's to tell? I'm a magistrate back in the city - it's all rather tedious.
780.context: NodeContext: We don't know he's a vampire yet.

618.speaker: Astarion
618.text: What's to tell? I was sired by a vampire named Cazador.

406.speaker: Astarion
406.text: Everything before that is so long ago it's ancient history. And everything that came after - well, I'd rather not reflect on it.

352.speaker: Player
352.text: You must remember your life before that?

223.speaker: Astarion
223.text: I was a magistrate, working to keep the peace in Baldur's Gate. Imprisoning trouble makers, that kind of thing.

417.speaker: Astarion
417.text: I can't remember much, truth be told. Centuries of torment will do that to you.

856.speaker: Astarion
856.text: I was attacked. A gang of vagrants, a tribe of wandering 'Gur', took issue with a ruling I'd made.

293.speaker: Astarion
293.text: They beat me to death's door when Cazador appeared. He chased them off and offered to save me. To give me eternal life.

226.speaker: Astarion
226.text: Given that my choices were 'eternal life' or 'bleed to death on the street', I took him up on the offer.

115.speaker: Astarion
115.text: It was only afterwards I realised just how long 'eternity' could be.

674.speaker: Player
674.context: NodeContext: with a sigh - you're explaining something that's obvious to you

499.speaker: Astarion
499.text: Why do you insist on exhuming the past?

103.speaker: Astarion
103.text: I was a slave, a vampire spawn, kept by the Szarr family.

727.speaker: Astarion
727.text: Perhaps I still am. I was never able to resist their commands.

491.speaker: Astarion
491.text: But now I've been conveniently lost. They won't ever control me again.

214.speaker: Player
214.text: How does someone become a vampire, exactly?
214.context: NodeContext: with a sigh - you're explaining something that's obvious to you

32.speaker: Astarion
32.text: It's simple. Just find a vampire that will drink your blood and turn you into a vampire spawn: their obedient puppet.
32.context: NodeContext: with a sigh - you're explaining something that's obvious to you

796.speaker: Astarion
796.text: In theory, the next step is to drink their blood. Once you've done that, you're free and a true vampire.
796.context: NodeContext: with a sigh - you're explaining something that's obvious to you

62.speaker: Player
62.context: NodeContext: with a sigh - you're explaining something that's obvious to you

284.speaker: Astarion
284.text: People think the biggest threat to a vampire is a cleric with a stake. It's not.
284.context: NodeContext: with a sigh - you're explaining something that's obvious to you

838.speaker: Astarion
838.text: The biggest threat to a vampire is another vampire. They're scheming, paranoid, power-hungry beasts.

412.speaker: Astarion
412.text: So why would any vampire give up control over a spawn to create a competitor?

65.speaker: Player
65.text: So they bite you, you bite them?

630.speaker: Astarion
630.text: Yes and no. The problem is once you're a vampire spawn, they completely control you. They have to allow you to bite them.

178.speaker: Astarion
178.text: And why would they do that? Vampires are power-hungry creatures. They won't lose a servant to create a competitor.

443.speaker: Player
443.text: You'd have to drink Cazador's blood to be free?

524.speaker: Astarion
524.text: Free and a true vampire, capable of creating my own coven? Yes.

535.speaker: Astarion
535.text: Although I'd settle for just killing the bastard. I wouldn't be a 'true' vampire, but I'd be free of him.

578.speaker: Player
578.text: I thought vampires couldn't walk into homes without an invitation.

620.speaker: Astarion
620.text: We can't. And yet I crossed the threshold like moonlight through leaves.

48.speaker: Astarion
48.text: This worm is a powerful little beast, isn't it?

179.speaker: Astarion
179.text: Oh don't be so glum. Look at the power it's bringing us.

682.speaker: Astarion
682.text: I can walk in sunlight, trespass upon any home, manipulate minds - there isn't another vampire in the Realms like me!

538.speaker: Player
538.text: It sounds like you're enjoying it.

509.speaker: Astarion
509.text: What's not to enjoy? I can walk in sunlight, trespass upon any home, manipulate minds - I'm the most powerful vampire in the Realms!

540.speaker: Astarion
540.text: Granted, the looming doom is an issue, but why not enjoy the benefits while we can?

473.speaker: Player
473.text: You wouldn't believe the conversation I've just had with Halsin...

83.speaker: Astarion
83.text: Ah, ha ha ha, I was wondering when you were going to ask me about this.

853.speaker: Astarion
853.text: I guessed. The man can't stay quiet about 'enjoying the freedom of Nature's gifts'. I bet he'd outlaw clothing if he could.

289.speaker: Player
289.text: So, you wouldn't mind? If I had something with him?

133.speaker: Player
133.text: I wouldn't even consider it if it bothered you.

669.speaker: Astarion
669.text: I'm happy for you to have as much Halsin as you wish - but I do have one question.

235.speaker: Astarion
235.text: It's not because... you know... we haven't... in a while?

667.speaker: Player
667.text: Gods, I don't want you to think that for a moment.

842.speaker: Astarion
842.text: I know I was being foolish. But thank you for saying it.

252.speaker: Player
252.text: I've admired Halsin for a while, that's all it is.

44.speaker: Astarion
44.text: I'm fairly sure the only one in the camp who hasn't is Withers, but even with him one can never be certain.

145.speaker: Player
145.text: He propositioned me out of nowhere - I just want to see where it goes.

592.speaker: Astarion
592.text: What hovel were you living in, that you didn't see this coming back in the grove? Honestly. But that's fine.

405.speaker: Player
405.text: What I have with you is wholly different and very special to me.

822.speaker: Player
822.text: I don't want you to feel bad, but I have felt frustrated.

141.speaker: Astarion
141.text: Oh. Well, you would. Wouldn't you? It makes sense.

639.speaker: Astarion
639.text: Go right on with Halsin. Far be it from me to hold your hunger against you.

692.speaker: Astarion
692.text: I trust you to make choices that are not going to hurt what we have.

138.speaker: Astarion
138.text: I trust you to make choices that are not going to hurt what we have.

278.speaker: Player
278.text: I want to see what happens with him.

418.speaker: Astarion
418.text: Honestly, so do I. What an adventure for you!

121.speaker: Player
121.text: I care for you a great deal. That's never changing.

211.speaker: Astarion
211.text: After all this, I've realised it's all right if it does change. If anything changes.

702.speaker: Player
702.text: I don't know what lies ahead, but I trust you, too.

345.speaker: Astarion
345.text: You're lucky I'm such an open-minded person.

706.speaker: Astarion
706.text: It doesn't concern me. You are mine. No one can change that.

686.speaker: Player
686.text: I'm still not sure about it. I wanted to get your thoughts.

689.speaker: Player
689.text: Did he talk to you about it?

474.speaker: Player
474.text: It's all right with you? You don't sound fazed...

384.speaker: Astarion
384.text: The druid is unique. He has a lot of experience with this type of arrangement.

487.speaker: Astarion
487.text: Thus, I'm sure it would be quite a harmless affair.

772.speaker: Player
772.text: I can't forgive myself for what happened between us.
772.context: InternalNodeContext: Met the Gur Hunter when Astarion was not with you. You did not know Astarion was a vampire at the time, but now you do.

688.speaker: Astarion
688.text: Just... don't make me think about it. Let's talk about something else. Anything else.

464.speaker: Player
464.context: InternalNodeContext: Met the Gur Hunter when Astarion was not with you. You did not know Astarion was a vampire at the time, but now you do.

552.speaker: Player
552.text: So, about you trying to bite me...
552.context: InternalNodeContext: Met the Gur Hunter when Astarion was not with you. You did not know Astarion was a vampire at the time, but now you do.

22.speaker: Player
22.text: I met a monster hunter in the swamp. He's not after you, is he?
22.context: InternalNodeContext: Met the Gur Hunter when Astarion was not with you. You did not know Astarion was a vampire at the time, but now you do.

79.speaker: Astarion
79.text: Excuse me? Not every monster hunter we stumble across is trying to kill me.

309.speaker: Astarion
309.text: Then again, we're not exactly keeping a low profile out here.

579.speaker: Astarion
579.text: Fine, I'll bite. What did he look like?
579.context: NodeContext: With a sigh. Responding to "someone might be hunting you" -> "who?" -> "dunno"

176.speaker: Player
176.text: Human, dark hair, lithe build. A Gur by the name of Gandrel.
176.context: NodeContext: With a sigh. Responding to "someone might be hunting you" -> "who?" -> "dunno"

808.speaker: Player
808.text: He was one of my people. Red-scaled and larger than I - an impressive warrior.
808.context: NodeContext: With a sigh. Responding to "someone might be hunting you" -> "who?" -> "dunno"

54.speaker: Astarion
54.text: That's interesting, but not the kind of person I'd expect to be hunting me.

248.speaker: Astarion
248.text: Still, it's wise to keep our eyes open. I'm hardly the only monster around here.

339.speaker: Player
339.text: I can't remember. I wasn't taking notes.
339.context: NodeContext: With a sigh. Responding to "someone might be hunting you" -> "who?" -> "dunno"

564.speaker: Astarion
564.text: Well, this has been very useful, thank you.
564.context: NodeContext: With a sigh. Responding to "someone might be hunting you" -> "who?" -> "dunno"

594.speaker: Astarion
594.text: Is there anything else? Any new and interesting ways you can waste my time?

26.speaker: Player
26.text: You can feed on me tonight, if you'd like.
26.context: InternalNodeContext: Met the Gur Hunter when Astarion was not with you. You knew Astarion was a vampire at the time.

381.speaker: Astarion
381.text: My sweet, there is nothing I'd like more.

157.speaker: Astarion
157.text: I'll come to you tonight, when you're snugly wrapped in your bedroll and we can have a little privacy.

302.speaker: Astarion
302.text: And this time I'll make sure I'm quiet - we don't want to disturb your rest.

672.speaker: Astarion
672.text: But I will taste you - savour you. Just enough to give me strength, and just enough to leave you wanting more.

638.speaker: Astarion
638.text: Later on, when we are at rest, I will eat you right up. Just enough to give me strength, and just enough to leave you wishing for more.

807.speaker: Astarion
807.text: I was just wondering when you'd invite me back for a bite.

75.speaker: Player
75.text: You may have heard... about me and Lae'zel.
75.context: InternalNodeContext: Met the Gur Hunter when Astarion was not with you. You knew Astarion was a vampire at the time.

256.speaker: Player
256.text: You may have heard... about me and Gale.
256.context: InternalNodeContext: Met the Gur Hunter when Astarion was not with you. You knew Astarion was a vampire at the time.

112.speaker: Player
112.text: You may have heard... about me and Wyll.
112.context: InternalNodeContext: Met the Gur Hunter when Astarion was not with you. You knew Astarion was a vampire at the time.

453.speaker: Player
453.text: You may have heard... about me and Karlach.
453.context: InternalNodeContext: Met the Gur Hunter when Astarion was not with you. You knew Astarion was a vampire at the time.

184.speaker: Player
184.text: You may have heard... about me and Shadowheart.
184.context: InternalNodeContext: Met the Gur Hunter when Astarion was not with you. You knew Astarion was a vampire at the time.

622.speaker: Player
622.text: We haven't spent a night together in quite some time...
622.context: InternalNodeContext: Met the Gur Hunter when Astarion was not with you. You knew Astarion was a vampire at the time.

775.speaker: Player
775.text: It's over between me and Karlach.
775.context: InternalNodeContext: Met the Gur Hunter when Astarion was not with you. You knew Astarion was a vampire at the time.

354.speaker: Player
354.text: It's over between me and Lae'zel.
354.context: InternalNodeContext: Met the Gur Hunter when Astarion was not with you. You knew Astarion was a vampire at the time.

73.speaker: Astarion
73.text: You really ended things with her, just to be with me?

566.speaker: Player
566.text: It's over between me and Shadowheart.
566.context: InternalNodeContext: Met the Gur Hunter when Astarion was not with you. You knew Astarion was a vampire at the time.

438.speaker: Player
438.text: It's over between me and Wyll.
438.context: InternalNodeContext: Met the Gur Hunter when Astarion was not with you. You knew Astarion was a vampire at the time.

250.speaker: Player
250.text: It's over between me and Gale.
250.context: InternalNodeContext: Met the Gur Hunter when Astarion was not with you. You knew Astarion was a vampire at the time.

377.speaker: Astarion
377.text: You really ended things with him, just to be with me?

476.speaker: Player
476.text: I want to discuss the Astral-Touched Tadpole.
476.context: InternalNodeContext: Met the Gur Hunter when Astarion was not with you. You knew Astarion was a vampire at the time.

568.speaker: Player
568.text: I met a monster hunter in the swamp. He was looking for you.
568.context: InternalNodeContext: Met the Gur Hunter when Astarion was not with you. You knew Astarion was a vampire at the time.

199.speaker: Player
199.text: He wanted to capture you and bring you back to Baldur's Gate.

359.speaker: Astarion
359.text: Back to Cazador. There's no other reason he'd want me alive.

824.speaker: Player
824.text: The hunter said you were a vampire spawn...

143.speaker: Astarion
143.text: Cazador Szarr is a vampire lord in Baldur's Gate. The patriarch of his coven and a monster obsessed with power.

543.speaker: Astarion
543.text: He turned me nearly two hundred years ago. I became his spawn and he became my tormentor.

38.speaker: Player
38.text: Why would Cazador want you alive?

537.speaker: Player
537.text: The hunter was a 'Gur'. Does that mean anything to you?

123.speaker: Astarion
123.text: Ha! Of course he'd send a Gur to hunt me down.

369.speaker: Player
369.text: He was a Gur, named Gandrel.

710.speaker: Astarion
710.text: A Gur? One of those vagabonds? Why would they -

462.speaker: Astarion
462.text: Cazador. Of course he'd send a Gur to hunt me down.

109.speaker: Player
109.text: Why? What's so special about the Gur people?

403.speaker: Astarion
403.text: They're not special, they're just easy to buy and morally vacuous. Perfect lackeys.

832.speaker: Astarion
832.text: First, they make excellent monster hunters. So 'find a vampire spawn' sounds perfectly reasonable to them.

118.speaker: Astarion
118.text: Second, they're the reason I'm like this in the first place. It was a group of Gur that attacked me that night in Baldur's Gate.

619.speaker: Astarion
619.text: I would've died had Cazador not appeared and saved me.

174.speaker: Player
174.text: Saved you by turning you into a vampire slave?

74.speaker: Astarion
74.text: Well, he didn't mention the 'slave' clause at the time.

126.speaker: Astarion
126.text: And now he sends a Gur monster hunter for me? It's a message.

55.speaker: Astarion
55.text: He's reminding me of his power. Even in the middle of nowhere, he can reach me. And he wants me back.

376.speaker: Player
376.text: You can't hold every Gur responsible for what happened to you.

33.speaker: Astarion
33.text: I think you'll find I can. And there's nothing your bleeding heart can do to change my mind.

203.speaker: Player
203.text: So why send one after you now? To remind you of that night?

240.speaker: Astarion
240.text: Perhaps. He probably thought it was funny.

262.speaker: Astarion
262.text: But more likely, he's trying to send me a message.

49.speaker: Player
49.text: He appeared just when you needed him? Sounds convenient.

754.speaker: Astarion
754.text: Maybe. Maybe he was just drawn to the smell of blood.

370.speaker: Astarion
370.text: The point is I have history with these barbarians. Cazador's sending a message.

845.speaker: Player
845.text: Why would monster hunters serve Cazador? He's a vampire!

488.speaker: Astarion
488.text: They may have no idea who they're working for. Cazador likely paid someone to pay someone to call in a favour, and here we are.

752.speaker: Astarion
752.text: He doesn't do simple plans. Not if he has a complex one that pits a dozen enemies against each other.

576.speaker: Astarion
576.text: No, this hunter is a message. Cazador's letting me know that even out here, he can get to me. He wants me back.

733.speaker: Player
733.text: But why capture you? Why not just kill you?

632.speaker: Astarion
632.text: Maybe he wants to make an example of me. To show what happens to runaways.

51.speaker: Astarion
51.text: Or maybe he thinks death is too good for me.

69.speaker: Astarion
69.text: Do you know the power a vampire lord possesses?

258.speaker: Astarion
258.text: He can change shape; turn into mist; call wolves to do his bidding; shrug off blows like they're nothing.

155.speaker: Astarion
155.text: He could walk into our camp tonight and kill you with his bare hands. And you'd be lucky if death was the worst thing that happened to you.

253.speaker: Player
253.text: All right. What do you suggest?

593.speaker: Astarion
593.text: ...I don't know. If we kill his lackeys, he'll just send more.

120.speaker: Player
120.text: Can he do that? Just walk into our camp?

301.speaker: Astarion
301.text: Probably not. He has to rest in his crypt during the day. I've never known him to leave Baldur's Gate.

557.speaker: Astarion
557.text: But he has no end of lackeys. He'll send someone else in his place.

504.speaker: Player
504.text: The Blade can handle a bloodsucker.

627.speaker: Astarion
627.text: Trust me, he's like nothing you've handled before.

580.speaker: Player
580.text: He sounds like a fine challenge.

382.speaker: Astarion
382.text: As much as I'd love to present his head to Vlaakith, you don't know what he's like.

512.speaker: Astarion
512.text: Just trust me when I say we need to be careful. He'll send more lackeys - he has plenty of souls to command.

431.speaker: Astarion
431.text: We just have to be vigilant. Keep our wits about us. And kill any monster hunters on sight.

229.speaker: Astarion
229.text: We can probably make an exception for Wyll. Probably...

263.speaker: Astarion
263.text: We can probably make an exception for Minsc. Probably...

441.speaker: Player
441.text: Vampires aren't invincible. We could take him.

584.speaker: Astarion
584.text: You don't understand. You don't know him.

343.speaker: Player
343.text: Sounds like he won't let you go easily. Should I be concerned?

210.speaker: Astarion
210.text: Concerned? Do you know the power a vampire lord possesses?

506.speaker: Astarion
506.text: How good of you to say, darling.

400.speaker: Astarion
400.text: Be sure to mention that if he saunters into our camp tonight. That'll save your neck.

567.speaker: Player
567.text: Don't worry - you're safe with me.

392.speaker: Player
392.text: But would a monster hunter work for a vampire?

111.speaker: Player
111.text: The monster hunter said he was working for someone called Ulma, not Cazador.

517.speaker: Astarion
517.text: Ulma? I don't know the name, but she might be worth talking to.

508.speaker: Astarion
508.text: Or killing. Whichever is more effective.

800.speaker: Astarion
800.text: But trust me, whoever these Gur are - Cazador has a hand in it. This hunter was a message.

738.speaker: Player
738.text: You're safe. Now tell me why you have a hunter on your tail.

326.speaker: Astarion
326.text: Why? Because Cazador sent him - why else?

482.speaker: Astarion
482.text: Tell me about this hunter - he obviously wasn't a vampire.

279.speaker: Astarion
279.text: Was he dragonborn? An orc? Something ferocious, surely?

701.speaker: Player
701.text: Human. A mild-mannered Gur named Gandrel.

811.speaker: Astarion
811.text: A Gur? A monster-hunting vagabond. His people are the reason I'm like this.

816.speaker: Astarion
816.text: It was a group of Gur that attacked me that night in Baldur's Gate. I would've died had Cazador not appeared and saved me.

43.speaker: Astarion
43.text: I thought so! Not that it matters, I trust you've taken care of it.

114.speaker: Astarion
114.text: But why send anyone after me? I'm hardly a threat out here.

149.speaker: Player
149.text: He wanted to capture you and bring you back to Baldur's Gate.

523.speaker: Player
523.text: It was a kobold with a limp. Terrifying.

327.speaker: Astarion
327.text: I suppose I shouldn't be surprised. Cazador always had a twisted sense of humour.

750.speaker: Player
750.text: Don't worry, he's been taken care of. Now tell me why you have a hunter on your tail.

809.speaker: Player
809.text: Are you really going to trust that devil to keep his word if we kill this orthon?
809.context: InternalNodeContext: Met the Gur Hunter with Astarion in your party. You knew he was a vampire at the time.

342.speaker: Astarion
342.text: I'd trust a devil over a vampire any day. I think he likes us.

514.speaker: Player
514.text: I like him, too. But I'd never say it to his smarmy face.

125.speaker: Astarion
125.text: Perhaps if we kill this orthon extra bloody, he'll invite us for tea and brandy back in his House.

454.speaker: Astarion
454.text: Am I not the very definition of 'careful'?

346.speaker: Player
346.text: Devils will take everything they can get. And more besides.

21.speaker: Astarion
21.text: Fret not, my soul is quite safe. I am not about to swap one master for another.

849.speaker: Astarion
849.text: Even though he's using me, I'm using him, too. And what do I care about this orthon's life?

771.speaker: Player
771.text: It's your only lead, I suppose.

648.speaker: Astarion
648.text: This is the first chance I've had to decipher my scars. Be a dear, don't get in my way.

728.speaker: Player
728.text: The orthon is dead. Aren't you pleased?
728.context: InternalNodeContext: Met the Gur Hunter with Astarion in your party. You knew he was a vampire at the time.

684.speaker: Player
684.text: So, there's a monster hunter after you?
684.context: InternalNodeContext: Met the Gur Hunter with Astarion in your party. You knew he was a vampire at the time.

472.speaker: Astarion
472.text: Not anymore. Which is all that matters, really.

681.speaker: Player
681.text: That monster hunter we met in the swamp - he's looking for you, isn't he?
681.context: InternalNodeContext: When you met the Gur Hunter, you didn't know Astarion was a vampire. You've since found out that he is.

735.speaker: Astarion
735.text: Hopefully he bumps into some gnolls while stumbling around at night and that's the last we hear from him.

421.speaker: Astarion
421.text: Then we kill him. I thought that would've been obvious.

447.speaker: Astarion
447.text: There may be others, of course. If Cazador sent one peon after me, he'll send more.

588.speaker: Player
588.text: That monster hunter you killed in the swamp - he was after you, wasn't he?
588.context: InternalNodeContext: You didn't know Astarion was a vampire when he killed the Gur. You've since discovered his secret.

628.speaker: Astarion
628.text: He was. But now he's not, which is all that matters, really.
628.context: NodeContext: Doesn't want to reveal that Cazador is a vampire lord - calls him slaver instead

132.speaker: Player
132.text: The hunter said you were a vampire spawn...
132.context: NodeContext: Doesn't want to reveal that Cazador is a vampire lord - calls him slaver instead

228.speaker: Astarion
228.text: Well of course he did. 'I'm hunting a poor innocent for money' isn't exactly going to win sympathy, is it?

510.speaker: Astarion
510.text: No, 'I'm here to save you from a monstrous vampire' - that's much more convincing.

665.speaker: Player
665.text: But why was he hunting you? What did you do?
665.context: NodeContext: Doesn't want to reveal that Cazador is a vampire lord - calls him slaver instead

456.speaker: Astarion
456.text: I didn't do anything! I was kidnapped - just like you.
456.context: NodeContext: Doesn't want to reveal that Cazador is a vampire lord - calls him slaver instead

583.speaker: Astarion
583.text: It seems Cazador wants me back.
583.context: NodeContext: Doesn't want to reveal that Cazador is a vampire lord - calls him slaver instead

271.speaker: Player
271.context: NodeContext: Doesn't want to reveal that Cazador is a vampire lord - calls him slaver instead

530.speaker: Astarion
530.text: Cazador Szarr is a vampire lord in Baldur's Gate. The patriarch of his coven and a monster obsessed with power.
530.context: NodeContext: Doesn't want to reveal that Cazador is a vampire lord - calls him slaver instead

467.speaker: Astarion
467.text: He turned me nearly two hundred years ago. I became his spawn and he became my tormentor.

839.speaker: Astarion
839.text: Ah, yes, you don't know. Cazador is a - a slaver in Baldur's Gate.
839.context: NodeContext: Doesn't want to reveal that Cazador is a vampire lord - calls him slaver instead

556.speaker: Astarion
556.text: He captured me a long time ago. Insisted I call him 'master' - I only escaped when the mind flayers snatched me away from him.

181.speaker: Astarion
181.text: I shouldn't be surprised Cazador's hunting me. He always was quite... obsessive.

312.speaker: Player
312.text: Cazador? The hunter said he was working for 'Ulma', the leader of his tribe.
312.context: NodeContext: 'them' said with disgust. He hates the Gur.

823.speaker: Astarion
823.text: He did. This 'Ulma' might be worth talking to.

80.speaker: Astarion
80.text: Or killing. They're both good options.

371.speaker: Astarion
371.text: But trust me, whoever the hunter thought he was working for, Cazador was pulling the strings. Only he would know to send the Gur after me.

713.speaker: Player
713.context: NodeContext: 'them' said with disgust. He hates the Gur.

698.speaker: Astarion
698.text: It was him, I'm sure. Only he would know to send the Gur after me.

135.speaker: Player
135.text: It was bad enough running from the mind flayers. Now your past is chasing us too?
135.context: NodeContext: 'them' said with disgust. He hates the Gur.

372.speaker: Astarion
372.text: I'm not happy about it either, you know. Especially for one of them to turn up.
372.context: NodeContext: 'them' said with disgust. He hates the Gur.

685.speaker: Player
685.text: What if there are others? He might not have been alone.

373.speaker: Astarion
373.text: Oh, there'll be others. I'm sure of that.

817.speaker: Astarion
817.text: If Cazador sent one peon after me, he'll send another.

549.speaker: Player
549.text: The next time someone comes looking for you, you're on your own.

607.speaker: Astarion
607.text: I appreciate your loyalty, darling, but I don't think you understand. My old master sent that vagabond after me.

3.speaker: Astarion
3.text: It was a mob of Gur that left me half-dead two hundred years ago. That left me begging Cazador to turn me so I could survive to take revenge.

471.speaker: Astarion
471.text: And if that old bastard wants me back, he won't ask whose side you're on before slaughtering you.

858.speaker: Player
858.text: You should know, I told that monster hunter where our camp was.

457.speaker: Astarion
457.text: What? Why? Why would you do that?!

599.speaker: Player
599.text: To lure him into an ambush. We can defeat him together.

651.speaker: Astarion
651.text: A sweet thought, but if he approaches a half-empty camp, he'll know something's wrong and bolt.

554.speaker: Astarion
554.text: Besides, this is... personal. It's better if I handle it alone.

691.speaker: Astarion
691.text: You go to bed as normal, I'll take first watch tonight. And if he appears, I'll be happy to take care of him.

776.speaker: Player
776.text: He's a monster hunter. You're a monster. Seemed fair?

12.speaker: Astarion
12.text: Fair? Nothing about this is fair. Least of all what you've done.

527.speaker: Astarion
527.text: If he can find me, anyone can. You've left me exposed.

315.speaker: Player
315.text: I wanted to see who'd win.

201.speaker: Astarion
201.text: No one's going to win, because there won't be a fight.

300.speaker: Astarion
300.text: I won't be caught and dragged back like some animal.

498.speaker: Astarion
498.text: When I return to Baldur's Gate, it will be on my terms. And if I can't trust you to help me, then I'll figure it out myself.

545.speaker: Astarion
545.text: I deserve better than anything that bounty hunter has planned for me, I promise you that.

255.speaker: Player
255.text: Have you been sneaking off during the night?
255.context: InternalNodeContext: We met Cazador in LOW, he asked us to bring Astarion to him.

411.speaker: Astarion
411.text: I've only been looking after us. That Gur hunter... he's passed by our camp once or twice in the darkness.

183.speaker: Player
183.text: You killed that monster hunter awful quickly.
183.context: InternalNodeContext: We met Cazador in LOW, he asked us to bring Astarion to him.

71.speaker: Astarion
71.text: Let me worry about the why. The Gur are duplicitous reprobates. Gods know what he was really after.

63.speaker: Astarion
63.text: He won't bother us anymore. Now I've made sure of it.

721.speaker: Player
721.text: No more impressive than you usually are.

626.speaker: Astarion
626.text: Aren't you just obsessed? And here I am, not even trying.

287.speaker: Astarion
287.text: Swear you'll look after me, and perhaps I won't need to go poking around with my knife.

204.speaker: Astarion
204.text: Oh, well, next time we can land the killing blow, together. It will be a bonding moment.

158.speaker: Player
158.text: It looked like you were almost ready to tear that monster hunter apart.
158.context: InternalNodeContext: We met Cazador in LOW, he asked us to bring Astarion to him.

617.speaker: Astarion
617.text: We're not wandering these wilds looking for stimulating conversations. Of course my knife was ready.

805.speaker: Astarion
805.text: The Gur are duplicitous. I've had my share of run-ins, so caution is only natural.

335.speaker: Player
335.text: What do you think is waiting for us at Moonrise Towers?
335.context: InternalNodeContext: We met Cazador in LOW, he asked us to bring Astarion to him.

225.speaker: Astarion
225.text: If Halsin is right, the person that's been playing games with the worms in our skulls.

290.speaker: Astarion
290.text: I don't know who they are, but I have plenty of questions.

571.speaker: Astarion
571.text: Who knows? Drow? Mind flayers? Death? Hopefully not ours.

117.speaker: Astarion
117.text: But maybe answers, if we can convince the right people to talk.

140.speaker: Player
140.text: What do you make of Raphael's deal?
140.context: InternalNodeContext: We met Cazador in LOW, he asked us to bring Astarion to him.

153.speaker: Astarion
153.text: I won't lie, it's tempting. If I keep the tadpole, I risk transforming into a grotesque monster.

168.speaker: Astarion
168.text: If I lose the tadpole, Cazador has control of me, body and soul, and I return to the shadows.

436.speaker: Astarion
436.text: It's grim either way, so why not sell what's left of my soul to a devil? Better he has it than Cazador.

577.speaker: Player
577.text: We have other options. Better options.

257.speaker: Astarion
257.text: Figuring out what's happening to us, confronting a god called 'the Absolute', and then finding the time to kill my old master before he can control me once more?

349.speaker: Astarion
349.text: Yes, that's an option. But I wouldn't bet eternity on it.

610.speaker: Astarion
610.text: I'm glad to hear it. Whatever's coming, we need to keep our options open.

129.speaker: Player
129.text: You're trading one master for another - you'll be a slave either way.

602.speaker: Astarion
602.text: You're familiar with the phrase 'better the devil you know'?

209.speaker: Astarion
209.text: I know Cazador. And I'll take anything that saves me from that.

334.speaker: Player
334.text: Consider telling him you worship Shar.
334.context: InternalNodeContext: We met Cazador in LOW, he asked us to bring Astarion to him.

401.speaker: Player
401.text: I can't believe you hid those scars from me.
401.context: InternalNodeContext: We met Cazador in LOW, he asked us to bring Astarion to him.

470.speaker: Player
470.text: What do you intend to do about Cazador's ritual?
470.context: InternalNodeContext: We met Cazador in LOW, he asked us to bring Astarion to him.

217.speaker: Player
217.text: I found Cazador. He wants me to bring you to him.
217.context: InternalNodeContext: We met Cazador in LOW, he asked us to bring Astarion to him.

86.speaker: Player
86.text: Cazador was preparing a dark ritual, but it's over. He's dead now.
86.context: InternalNodeContext: Player killed Cazador, but were not told explicitly what the ritual's purpose was.

541.speaker: Astarion
541.text: What do you mean 'dead'? How? Why?!

857.speaker: Astarion
857.text: Free? I'm not free - I'm trapped!

606.speaker: Astarion
606.text: I'll never be anything but a spawn now. You've sentenced me to an eternity in darkness.

280.speaker: Astarion
280.text: Tell me honestly, did you kill him for my sake or to stop me completing the ritual myself?

270.speaker: Player
270.text: No, I did it for you. Because I wanted you to be safe.

600.speaker: Astarion
600.text: I - ...I do believe you. I know you only did what you thought was best for me.

395.speaker: Astarion
395.text: And who knows - maybe this is what's best? The kind of power that ritual offered could ruin a person. Even me.

797.speaker: Astarion
797.text: Gods, I would have liked to kill him, though.

783.speaker: Player
783.text: Trust me, this was for the best.

562.speaker: Astarion
562.text: I will have to trust you on that.

45.speaker: Astarion
45.text: You know, on some level, it does.

410.speaker: Player
410.text: You should know, Cazador turned the victims you brought him to spawn. They were sacrifices for the ritual.

725.speaker: Astarion
725.text: They - they were alive? All this time, they were just hidden under the palace?

582.speaker: Astarion
582.text: Hells. After two centuries, Cazador still had new horrors to reveal.

17.speaker: Astarion
17.text: What did you do with the poor wretches?

95.speaker: Player
95.text: I set them free - they're in the Underdark now.

747.speaker: Astarion
747.text: That was a kindness. I think? It's hard to know, really.

798.speaker: Astarion
798.text: I'm not sure if I feel worse for them or the creatures of the Underdark. But at least they're free.

544.speaker: Astarion
544.text: I suppose they're at peace, if nothing else. Or whatever passes for peace these days.

39.speaker: Astarion
39.text: Gods. Well, maybe it's for the best. I don't know if killing them feels right, but freeing them? I'm not sure the world is ready to have seven thousand hungry spawn unleashed on it.

834.speaker: Astarion
834.text: Still, this will take some getting used to - Cazador being... gone.

859.speaker: Astarion
859.text: I just need some time to let it sink in - to figure out what it means now that he's gone.

331.speaker: Player
331.text: Of course, take all the time you need.

150.speaker: Astarion
150.text: Thank you. And thank you for what you did.

591.speaker: Astarion
591.text: I thought Cazador's story would end with more of a bang than a whimper, but... well, you did end it. I'm grateful.

307.speaker: Player
307.text: Don't worry, I'll accept those thanks whenever you're ready.

837.speaker: Astarion
837.text: You may be waiting a while. This has brought up some complicated feelings.

829.speaker: Player
829.text: It's all right, I wanted to talk about something else anyway.

288.speaker: Astarion
288.text: You choose now to have a chat? This exact moment?

27.speaker: Astarion
27.text: Your timing is incredible, but all right. What do you want?

654.speaker: Player
654.text: I left them in the care of some monster hunters. They were waiting when I left.

58.speaker: Astarion
58.text: Gods help them. But perhaps they'll find some kind of peace at the end of all this.

14.speaker: Player
14.text: What would you have liked me to do?

390.speaker: Astarion
390.text: I don't know. I don't know what I would have done - what I could have done, even.

763.speaker: Astarion
763.text: Just - I just need some space. I'm sure this will all start to sink in soon.

102.speaker: Player
102.text: Feeling guilty all of a sudden?

397.speaker: Astarion
397.text: I don't know what I feel right now. I'm trying to absorb everything and - hells, it's so much...

819.speaker: Player
819.text: Don't worry, we'll find you something else to kill.

744.speaker: Player
744.text: No, I did it for you. Because I wanted you to be safe.

423.speaker: Astarion
423.text: Safe? How can I ever be safe now?

374.text: Safe? How can I ever be safe now?

273.speaker: Astarion
273.text: Safe? How can I ever be safe now?

716.speaker: Astarion
716.text: That ritual was my one shot at security, at independence - and you snatched it from my hands.

613.speaker: Player
613.text: If you'd completed the ritual, you would've become just like Cazador.

251.speaker: Astarion
251.text: I - ...I do understand - there's always a risk we'll become the monsters we want to slay.

743.speaker: Astarion
743.text: I - ...I do understand - there's always a risk we'll become the monsters we want to slay.

852.speaker: Astarion
852.text: I'll never say you saved me from him, but perhaps you saved me from myself...

366.speaker: Player
366.text: The ritual had nothing to do with it.

171.speaker: Astarion
171.text: All right. If you say so, then I believe you.

658.speaker: Astarion
658.text: All right. If you say so, then I believe you.

794.speaker: Astarion
794.text: Although maybe the ritual could have something to do with it. I did immediately accuse you of plotting to keep me from it...

732.speaker: Player
732.text: Yes. No one should have that much power.

495.speaker: Astarion
495.text: I could have had that much power! I could have walked in the sun!

615.speaker: Astarion
615.text: And now you have the gall to stand here and announce that you've doomed me to this life forever.

195.speaker: Player
195.text: Your life will be whatever you make it, so focus on making it a good one.

848.speaker: Astarion
848.text: Easy to say when you're not the one facing a lifetime of hunger in the shadows.

501.speaker: Player
501.text: I did what I thought was right. I won't apologise for that.

478.speaker: Astarion
478.text: Whatever your fears, this is my life. It should have been my choice, and you should have trusted me to make it.

605.speaker: Astarion
605.text: We've come so far together, we may as well see this tadpole business through to the end. But once that's done, we're done.

439.speaker: Astarion
439.text: Now leave me be. I have a lot to think about.

291.speaker: Astarion
291.text: We have been through a lot, but this? This is too much.

587.speaker: Astarion
587.text: If I were in a position to, I'd leave you here and now. Lucky for you, I'll have to stick around a little longer.

793.speaker: Astarion
793.text: You can deal with the tadpole yourself. I'm done with you.

660.speaker: Astarion
660.text: I had a chance to live forever in the sun. To be free of the hunger that wracks me day and night.

82.speaker: Player
82.text: I suppose gratitude was too much to hope for.

503.speaker: Player
503.text: It was too risky for you to face him.

786.speaker: Astarion
786.text: Because he was my master or because you thought I couldn't resist finishing the ritual myself?

516.speaker: Astarion
516.text: Because you robbed me of the chance to do it.

432.speaker: Astarion
432.text: You stole my chance at vengeance - my chance to become more than some wretched spawn.

239.speaker: Player
239.text: The ritual had to be stopped. No one should have that much power.

208.speaker: Player
208.text: Cazador was preparing a dark ritual, but it's over. He's dead now.
208.context: InternalNodeContext: Player killed Cazador after he told them about the ritual.

187.speaker: Player
187.context: InternalNodeContext: Player killed Cazador, but knew about the ritual already.

804.speaker: Player
804.text: You should know, Cazador turned the victims you brought him to spawn. They were sacrifices for the ritual.
804.context: InternalNodeContext: Player asks Astarion why he wants Raphael to look into his scars. Available between Astarion saying he wants to speak to Raphael and Astarion getting Raphael's Revelation OR player telling Astarion that Raphael's left Act 2.

59.speaker: Player
59.text: Why ask Raphael about your scars? What's your plan?
59.context: InternalNodeContext: Player asks Astarion why he wants Raphael to look into his scars. Available between Astarion saying he wants to speak to Raphael and Astarion getting Raphael's Revelation OR player telling Astarion that Raphael's left Act 2.

450.speaker: Astarion
450.text: It's not a plan yet - more a feeling. Just an itch at the back of my mind, but I know I'm missing something.

548.speaker: Astarion
548.text: Whatever Cazador did to me, it was more than his usual sadism: it had purpose.

413.speaker: Astarion
413.text: Once I know what that purpose was, maybe a plan will present itself. But for now I just need to scratch this itch.

98.speaker: Player
98.text: I met Raphael - I know you were looking for him.
98.context: InternalNodeContext: Player tells Astarion they met Raphael and he gave them the mission to kill the Orthon without Astarion being present.

774.speaker: Astarion
774.text: You did? Gods damn it, I wanted to be there! I wanted to make a deal...

507.speaker: Astarion
507.text: All right, so what did the old devil have to say?

409.speaker: Player
409.text: He wants us to kill something - an old enemy of his.

361.speaker: Player
361.text: Why does it matter? We can't trust him.

230.speaker: Astarion
230.text: He doesn't have to be trustworthy to be useful. None of us do.

767.speaker: Astarion
767.text: Perhaps if we help him, I can still salvage something from this. He would owe us, after all...

425.speaker: Astarion
425.text: Yes... Yes, this might work! Now we just need to get on his good side.

569.speaker: Astarion
569.text: If we do as he asks, he'll be in our debt. And if he's in our debt, he can tell me everything there is to know about my scars...

788.speaker: Astarion
788.text: Please understand, this is important. I need to ask Raphael about some scars Cazador left on my back.

664.speaker: Astarion
664.text: He carved them into my back over one long night, saying it was a poem. But it's more than that, I'm sure.

624.speaker: Astarion
624.text: Whatever he wrote, he wrote it in Infernal. And if anyone can reveal infernal secrets - Raphael can. That's why we have to do as he asks.

286.speaker: Astarion
286.text: Not to you, maybe, but it's important to me.

835.speaker: Player
835.text: Are you worried about Cazador finding out you're back?
835.context: InternalNodeContext: Arriving in Wyrm's Crossing, the player asks Astarion how he's feeling about Cazador knowing he's there

751.speaker: Astarion
751.text: I won't lie, the thought hardly fills me with glee. Even with my new-found advantages, he's still an incredibly powerful vampire.

485.speaker: Astarion
485.text: But he's arrogant too. If he does hear I'm back, he'll try to take me and expose himself in the process. Then I'll be able to strike.

604.speaker: Astarion
604.text: It's something of a gamble, true, but if I can win - if I can beat him, it would be worth any risk.

720.speaker: Astarion
720.text: So yes, I do worry about facing him. But if we can get his attention, finding the ritual's location will be much easier, and that could give me the edge I need.

206.speaker: Player
206.text: And how will you 'strike' exactly? He won't be alone.

647.speaker: Astarion
647.text: Neither will I, darling. At least I hope you'll come along for the show?

550.speaker: Astarion
550.text: But regardless, the plan is simple - find him, stop him from gaining almighty power, and then really enjoy killing him.

0.speaker: Astarion
0.text: And if I can seize that almighty power for myself? Well, all the better.

148.speaker: Player
148.text: You really think you can beat him?

575.speaker: Player
575.text: So you unlocked the Necromancy of Thay. Did you find what you were looking for?
575.context: NodeContext: Cautiously putting the idea of not stopping the ritual out there

847.speaker: Astarion
847.text: It is full of terrible secrets, including Cazador's bloody 'Rite of Profane Ascension', but it told me nothing new.

687.speaker: Astarion
687.text: Then again, it was filled with otherworldly power. Which I am more than happy to wield to my advantage.

419.speaker: Astarion
419.text: I was hoping for something that would let me escape whatever fate Cazador had planned for me. Instead, I found the Rite of Profane Ascension.

696.speaker: Astarion
696.text: It grants my kind the freedom to walk in the sun, be free of our hunger, and accrue all manner of powers.

244.speaker: Astarion
244.text: All it requires is the sacrifice of a few souls. Souls by scars that look exactly like mine.

379.speaker: Astarion
379.text: This rite - it's been Cazador's plan the whole time. He's going to sacrifice me and who knows how many others so he can 'ascend' to all this power.

317.speaker: Astarion
317.text: I'm sorry, I... I might need a moment. This is a lot to take in...

404.speaker: Player
404.text: I wanted to ask about Cazador's ritual. You must be thinking about it?
404.context: NodeContext: Cautiously putting the idea of not stopping the ritual out there

76.speaker: Astarion
76.text: The thing that will decide my fate forevermore? Yes, it has been on my mind - why?
76.context: NodeContext: Cautiously putting the idea of not stopping the ritual out there

563.speaker: Player
563.text: Do you think we can stop it?
563.context: NodeContext: Cautiously putting the idea of not stopping the ritual out there

247.speaker: Astarion
247.text: Well, in theory it's simple: destroy Cazador, stop ritual. That's assuming we want to stop the ritual...
247.context: NodeContext: Cautiously putting the idea of not stopping the ritual out there

81.speaker: Astarion
81.text: What? I've obviously thought about it! If I was the one who completed the ritual, I'd have such power. And I could walk in the sun without fear I'd turn into a mind flayer.

714.speaker: Player
714.text: I don't think you should do it.

748.speaker: Astarion
748.text: A pity then, that it's not your decision to make.

136.speaker: Astarion
136.text: Of course, I don't even know if I could complete the ritual. It may be impossible - but it certainly is tempting.

282.speaker: Player
282.text: And the souls that need to be sacrificed?

164.speaker: Astarion
164.text: I don't relish it, but my siblings lured thousands of people to their deaths over the years. I doubt Baldur's Gate would miss them.

105.speaker: Player
105.text: I just want to know what your intentions are.
105.context: NodeContext: Cautiously putting the idea of not stopping the ritual out there

676.speaker: Astarion
676.text: I hadn't really decided on the specifics. Obviously we could stop the ritual, or... not?
676.context: NodeContext: Cautiously putting the idea of not stopping the ritual out there

536.speaker: Player
536.text: All that power - you must be tempted to take it for yourself.

396.speaker: Astarion
396.text: Well, of course I've thought about it. If I completed the ritual instead of Cazador, I'd get all that power. And I could walk in the sun without fear I'd turn into a mind flayer.

162.speaker: Player
162.text: I never asked - are you Cazador's only spawn? Or are there others like you?
162.context: InternalNodeContext: Asked Astarion if there are any other spawn. Triggers in Act 2 if you've asked about his history with Cazador.

320.speaker: Astarion
320.text: Cazador sired seven spawn - me and my six 'brothers and sisters'.

782.speaker: Astarion
782.text: He always insisted we were a family - even when he was carving scars into our flesh.

8.speaker: Astarion
8.text: I was one of his first, some of the others came years later. He was a monster to us all, but did take special pleasure in my pain. He said my screams sounded sweetest.

323.speaker: Astarion
323.text: And now that I'm gone... I don't know. I pity the other six...
